# News comment title:
Our Sadly Lowered Standards for Dickitude

# Oldest comment (from the thread):
"But by far the most significant part of it is the right's mastery of the media."

Not mastery, ownership. Ownership. It begins and ends there. It's hard to master the media when your side is only invited on to serve as either token or punching bag.

# Most liked comment (from the thread):
If only we had a vice president able to push back--hard, all the time. And not jut push back, but push forward. Biden could change the national conversation. He's already got the reputation for plainspoken gaffes. Send him out saying, 'The Republicans are sabotaging the economy for political gain.' Then have him apologize, and say it again. And again. Isn't that the political niche of the vice-president? Why isn't he being used?

>>> COMMENT UNDER ANALYSIS<<<


The race card is overplayed. Conservatives do NOT care one damn bit about his race. We only care about his politics. Which is why we didn't support Hilary for president either(Oh wait that's because we're also sexists). Well we didn't support Bill either(Oh right because he was really the first black president). 

I dislike him for his extreme left liberal policies, for his massive spending programs and his disregard of the constitution. I also personally dislike him because he threw Israel, our only ally in the middle east and the only free nation in the middle east, under the bus.

>>> END COMMENT <<<

# News comment title:
Which Is Better: Hybrid or Fuel-Efficient Conventional?

# Oldest comment (from the thread):
I just purchased a 2012 Hyundai Accent, in a large part for the mileage. Like you, most of mt trips are distance ones, not city ones, and the highway mileage on the new Accent is 40 mpg. 

# Most liked comment (from the thread):
The cleanest car is a turbodiesel. Diesel fuel has more energy per gallon than regular unleaded and the engine is much more efficient. Plus, you don't have the environmental disaster that goes along with lithium or nickel mining.

>>> COMMENT UNDER ANALYSIS<<<


i like the new diesel cars. plus you cant beat the vw commercials. i wonder if the vw can handle biodiesel and if they can come up with more efficient ways to produce the biodiesel. i havent really studied the topic at all yet. *goes to study biodiesel*

>>> END COMMENT <<<

# News comment title:
Michele Bachmann's Child Army

# Oldest comment (from the thread):
If you get a chance, please watch the documentary "Jesus Camp".  Traumatized Home-schooled children are forced to worship the feet of a life-size cardboard cut-out of George W. Bush.

Much like Michele Bachmann did at the 2007 SOTU speech.

I kid you NOT !

Calling this "child abuse" is putting it mildly.



# Most liked comment (from the thread):
If you get a chance, please watch the documentary "Jesus Camp".  Traumatized Home-schooled children are forced to worship the feet of a life-size cardboard cut-out of George W. Bush.

Much like Michele Bachmann did at the 2007 SOTU speech.

I kid you NOT !

Calling this "child abuse" is putting it mildly.



>>> COMMENT UNDER ANALYSIS<<<


I'm actually not for the complete privatization of the school system. Let's see... I'll try to list out what I would do to reform the education system, a lot of this is based on the japanese system. some of it is not. The education sytsem was on decline long before no child left behind, however it definitely screwed it up further. It stemmed from the idea that everyone had to be treated equally when it's obvious that people think and learn in very different ways.

1) Allow vouchers. It will allow competition which should reduce costs and raise school quality. It has nothing to do with the amount of income a school gets, we can see this by looking at the lack of correlation between increased funds and grades.

2) Modify tenure so that if a teacher is sitting on his/her ass not actually teaching they can be fired no matter what

3) Mandated education ends at 16 (Junior High). After that entrance exams will help you get into specific senior high schools. If you choose to. Alternative trade schools, etc should also be opened up.

4) And this one is also gonna piss off a lot of people. Get rid of the massive summer vacation. It was created because on average students lived on family farms so they needed to be off during the summer months.

4a) Convert the current school system to a trimester system with smaller breaks and a shorter summer vacation in the middle of the school year so that work can be assigned over it. This will prevent the issue of having to re-teach/relearn all the material that has for far too long been forgotten over long summer vacations.

5) This one is going to be the absolute most difficult one. We need to get families involved once again in the education process. There are so many parents who don't give a damn about what kind of education their child gets. Partially because the parent has no choice. The voucher system as well as the senior high setup should help with that a bit but... it's gonna take time and effort.

*thinks* I'm sure there's more but 

>>> END COMMENT <<<

# News comment title:
Thanks for the Cooling, Volcanoes

# Oldest comment (from the thread):
It seems that if we want to lower the climate a couple degrees we need to bomb a volcano or two and the resulting eruptions will cool the earth for a couple years, then maybe if we bombed enough of them we could create a mini iceage and refreeze the polar ice caps... then we only have to worry about the acid rain...  Oh well one problem at a time...

I know... I know...

# Most liked comment (from the thread):
Volcanoes cool the planet, but all the hot air spewed by the people on Fox anti-News warms it.

>>> COMMENT UNDER ANALYSIS<<<


No, you are confusing theory with facts.

Data are facts, cause and effect are always theories no matter how solid. Even the theory of gravity is a theory not a fact. You see, theories are fluid, facts are not. 

"FACT:  The anthropogenic increase in CO2 levels is causing the Earth system to retain more of the Sun's energy, and thus heat up.  The change in the Earth's energy balance resulting from the anthropogenic excess of CO2 has been directly measured."

We actually do not know how CO2 interacts with other gasses in our atmosphere to trap energy from the sun or whether or not it is a direct linear effect or if the effect is super-linear, sub-linear, a function of only concentration, a function of concentration and temperature, etc.

As soon as you add the word "cause" you no longer have a fact. You have a theory.

"The ball fell." fact
"Gravity caused the ball to fall." theory

>>> END COMMENT <<<

# News comment title:
What the USDA Doesn't Want You to Know About Antibiotics and Factory Farms

# Oldest comment (from the thread):
the provided link has been removed. Way to go, Government. Glad you're 'for the poeple'. YOU SUCK!!!

# Most liked comment (from the thread):
I often hear the expense argument: that antibiotic and hormone-free meat is a yuppie luxury. But the low prices that we have for meat are artificially so. They are the result of severe overcrowding, which necessitates the routine use of antibiotics -- a HUGE problem. What does it tell us that beef importation is banned in Europe? The European Union simply does not allow the ridiculous, unscrupulous, and irresponsible (on so many levels) farming methods that are now the norm in the U.S. I am a meat-eater. I am also on a budget. What I find is a better solution than buying crappy meat and eating a ton of it (Americans eat far more meat than we need or is healthy), I simply buy quality meat, stock up when it's on sale and freeze in usable portions, eat less of it, and eat more beans and whole grains to complement the protein from the meat. There are other solutions. Many of us just don't want to find them, as it's slightly inconvenient. We've gotten used to such an unhealthy lifestyle and it's killing us en-masse. What is more expensive in the long run? 

>>> COMMENT UNDER ANALYSIS<<<


While being a vegetarian or vegan has its benefits, it is very easy to fall into the trap of not getting the proper nutrients. I've noticed a lot of people who switch over have to eat more and so tend to gain weight too. Also it doesn't matter veggies or meat, massive improper farming techniques causes just as much destruction when they're growing veggies. Devestation of natural lands, etc. Also don't forget all the pesticides, etc.

The best idea is going local, not organic. Unfortunately USDA has put so many restrictions, especially cost wise, on organic farming that only the mega farms can afford to be labled organic. People don't need to worry about the organic lable as long as they know the source is a good source and that's why local works.

# News comment title:
The Deal With $8 Eggs

# Oldest comment (from the thread):
Very strange looking hogs in the picture.

# Most liked comment (from the thread):
Good article. There is actually a 4th mode of production that isn't even widely considered, which is neighborhood based farming. Now I know this concept sounds a bit absurd, and like a throw back to the dark ages, but listen for a moment.

What our industrial  production systems do in general is they exchange inefficient use of labor for inefficient use of raw materials. Things get cheaper because less labor is used to produce them, but in fact we use more raw materials in the production process so we actually waste more material, but the cost of the excess material itself goes down due to the same process of reducing labor costs for acquisition of the raw materials.

Now this is most acute when applied to food production, and within food production it is most acute when applied to animal food production.

The REAL value of animals as a food source is that animals can convert material inedible to humans into an edible form, in other words goats can forage on weeds and grass and trash, things we can't eat, and turn it into meat, something we can eat.

In a more primitive sense, buffalo and deer can forage on grass and trees and turn it into meat, etc.

So this works efficiently when animals are turning things we can't eat into stuff we can eat. But that's not how we raise livestock now, now we grow human edible food and then feed it to animals, which defeats the whole purpose of even eating animals.

 So, aside from proscribing vegetarianism, if animals are indeed to be grown and harvested for food we should be using them only to consume things that we can't eat and turn it into edible meat, converting "waste" into something useful.

Now, we also have a MASSIVE problem of food waste in America, and this stems from waste of foods and home and in restaurants. What happens with this food is that it gets thrown into the trash and goes to land fills, where sea gulls and vulchers eat a portion of it and he rest rots in the ground getting eaten by microbes and bugs.

What we should be doing is community based pig, goat, and chicken farming and feeding the animals the waste from our homes and restaurants, thus converting waste into something useful, solving two problems at once.

But we don't do this for two primary reasons. #1 is zoning. With the rise of urbanization and modernization having farm animals among the people was undesirable by the citizens who appealed to legislators to make it illegal to raise farm animals in residential areas, and also it was seen as primitive and backwards to have farm animals in cosmopolitan areas so city leaders, etc didn't want that. Plus there is the real issue of public health and animals were seen and spreaders of disease, which is partly true. So that's the firs tissue, zoning.

Issue #2 is labor and scale, again going back to the first point of trading efficient use of material for efficient use of labor. While it uses less raw material, or makes better use of raw material, to do community based farming and use community waste as the food source, you can't get the scale or the efficiency in terms of labor, so it becomes more cost effective to just buy farmed corn than to try and collect waste and process it and distribute it among smaller and distributed facilities, etc.

But, ultimately, this is where we need to go. We need to work on reversing the zoning restrictions against farming in residential areas and we need to move to a "food waste to farm" system where the recycle our food waste back into the food chain, as was traditionally done for thousands of years (because it was a more efficient use of raw material, and thus also labor in an non industrialized system)

>>> COMMENT UNDER ANALYSIS<<<


I do like neighborhood based farming. I wanted to start a company that ran small apartment groups that were energy efficient, etc and had a group garden. Dunno, I have no cash to even consider the idea, so oh well.

>>> END COMMENT <<<

# News comment title:
The Deal With $8 Eggs

# Oldest comment (from the thread):
Very strange looking hogs in the picture.

# Most liked comment (from the thread):
Good article. There is actually a 4th mode of production that isn't even widely considered, which is neighborhood based farming. Now I know this concept sounds a bit absurd, and like a throw back to the dark ages, but listen for a moment.

What our industrial  production systems do in general is they exchange inefficient use of labor for inefficient use of raw materials. Things get cheaper because less labor is used to produce them, but in fact we use more raw materials in the production process so we actually waste more material, but the cost of the excess material itself goes down due to the same process of reducing labor costs for acquisition of the raw materials.

Now this is most acute when applied to food production, and within food production it is most acute when applied to animal food production.

The REAL value of animals as a food source is that animals can convert material inedible to humans into an edible form, in other words goats can forage on weeds and grass and trash, things we can't eat, and turn it into meat, something we can eat.

In a more primitive sense, buffalo and deer can forage on grass and trees and turn it into meat, etc.

So this works efficiently when animals are turning things we can't eat into stuff we can eat. But that's not how we raise livestock now, now we grow human edible food and then feed it to animals, which defeats the whole purpose of even eating animals.

 So, aside from proscribing vegetarianism, if animals are indeed to be grown and harvested for food we should be using them only to consume things that we can't eat and turn it into edible meat, converting "waste" into something useful.

Now, we also have a MASSIVE problem of food waste in America, and this stems from waste of foods and home and in restaurants. What happens with this food is that it gets thrown into the trash and goes to land fills, where sea gulls and vulchers eat a portion of it and he rest rots in the ground getting eaten by microbes and bugs.

What we should be doing is community based pig, goat, and chicken farming and feeding the animals the waste from our homes and restaurants, thus converting waste into something useful, solving two problems at once.

But we don't do this for two primary reasons. #1 is zoning. With the rise of urbanization and modernization having farm animals among the people was undesirable by the citizens who appealed to legislators to make it illegal to raise farm animals in residential areas, and also it was seen as primitive and backwards to have farm animals in cosmopolitan areas so city leaders, etc didn't want that. Plus there is the real issue of public health and animals were seen and spreaders of disease, which is partly true. So that's the firs tissue, zoning.

Issue #2 is labor and scale, again going back to the first point of trading efficient use of material for efficient use of labor. While it uses less raw material, or makes better use of raw material, to do community based farming and use community waste as the food source, you can't get the scale or the efficiency in terms of labor, so it becomes more cost effective to just buy farmed corn than to try and collect waste and process it and distribute it among smaller and distributed facilities, etc.

But, ultimately, this is where we need to go. We need to work on reversing the zoning restrictions against farming in residential areas and we need to move to a "food waste to farm" system where the recycle our food waste back into the food chain, as was traditionally done for thousands of years (because it was a more efficient use of raw material, and thus also labor in an non industrialized system)

>>> COMMENT UNDER ANALYSIS<<<


There's definitely going to be a difference in price point. Remember, there isn't a single price that allows for production or a single price that allows for sales. It's a whole range and is often effected by consumer opinion. Though there is a limit of course.

I don't see the term organic going away all together, though most likely what you will see is a trend towards a naturally produced sustainable product as just being the norm.

>>> END COMMENT <<<

# News comment title:
$4 Gas: Brought to You by Wall Street

# Oldest comment (from the thread):
I've been saying this for years, this attempt to control the market on gasoline is partially what is responsible for the crash in the auto industry, because when gas prices reached the stratosphere, that is when people stopped buying cars, sending the industry into a tailspin and necessitating the auto bailouts.     There was a little bit of poetic justice since these speculators got stuck needing to eventually take delivery on all that gasoline, and having nowhere to put it, had to dump it, which caused the big drop in gas prices we enjoyed for a little while.   But not to be deterred, they are back in the market once again today, because gas prices are still going up despite the fact demand is way down due to the recession and oil prices in general are way below what they were even a year ago.   And we are being told that these high prices are due to demand in other parts of the world.   Poppycock, if that were true the price of OIL would be going up as well!   We aren't that stupid!!

# Most liked comment (from the thread):

I want to deny these pigs evey penny possible.

>>> COMMENT UNDER ANALYSIS<<<


Of course we'll ignore the $0.50 - $1.00 per gallon that's added onto directly to our gasoline. Plus the hidden costs of taxes that have been embedded in the cost.

We'll also ignore the cost of adding a minimum of 10% ethanol to every gallon of gas. Ethanol burns less efficiently and has a lower energy content than gasoline so you do not get as many miles to the gallon. Plus it's hydrophilic (draws in water) so it damages the car as you burn it.

Removing the gas taxes alone would reduce the price of gas by about $0.60 on average and removing the ethanol would increase your mileage and life span of your car.

# News comment title:

# Oldest comment (from the thread):
And we are left thinking how many would have voted Ron Paul if the media wouldn't have constantly screamed that hes unelectable....

# Most liked comment (from the thread):
Actually, on many fronts Obama's image is starting to improve. So-called "Obamacare" is turning out to be a good thing for many with more people realizing that it is a step forward into the 21st century for the US. We are the only industrialized nation that leaves health benefits to the whim of the employer or the vagaries of the insurance companies and it hurts us.

>>> COMMENT UNDER ANALYSIS<<<


Our profit based system provides for some of the fastest innovation of any medical industry. Stop comparing England's health care system to Canada's. In the case of England the system is centralized, and in the case of Canada it's decentralized. That's why Canada's government isn't collapsing under its own debt like England's system is.

As to your jab, I read all pieces of information, verify, and then incorporate the data into my conclusions.

The statement that it is unconstitutional for the federal government to require the purchasing a product is a completely valid one. In order to invoke the interstate commerce clause there must exist the act of purchasing across state. In other words, the federal government can regulate action, it can not regulate inaction.

>>> END COMMENT <<<

# News comment title:
Why Conservatives' Favorite New Study on Gay Parenting Won't Matter

# Oldest comment (from the thread):
I'd say, if they do worse, it's likely the result of social attitudes toward their parents gay families. The tail is wagging the dog here.

# Most liked comment (from the thread):
I'd say, if they do worse, it's likely the result of social attitudes toward their parents gay families. The tail is wagging the dog here.

>>> COMMENT UNDER ANALYSIS<<<


Well I'm not really sure, but I'd say there would be a possibility that without a role model of both common genders found in our culture, the child might have an issue adapting to a gender role.

Obviously gender roles aren't based on biology; I said multiple times that they are based on culture--if culture changes and indeed gender becomes an antiquated concept then that's fine, but it most definitely is not antiquated as of right now: if a man walks into a room with a ballroom gown on, do you think that people aren't going to stop and ask what the hell he's doing?

Again, I am not looking at this from a good or bad perspective, or whether or not it's going to shift cultural norms, but you are absolutely wrong if you think that cultural norms in our society do not include gender roles, and I think you are indeed being naive if you think that a person who does not fit into current gender norms is going to have as easy a time in our culture as someone who does.

>>> END COMMENT <<<

# News comment title:
The American Diet in 1 Chart

# Oldest comment (from the thread):
Here is an article that outlines some of the less than healthy prepared food choices that are available to American consumers that provide an entire day's fat or sodium content in a single serving:

http://viableopposition.blogspot.ca/2011/08/america-eats-and-eatsand-then-eats-some.html

It's no wonder there is an epidemic of obesity.

# Most liked comment (from the thread):
Robert Reich outlined the decline of the middle class as follows:

- Job/Salary stagnation which was compensated for by
- Parttime extra jobs and more hours, when it got more extreme
- Both spouses working and, when it got more extreme
- Credit card debt propped up by hopes for a bright housing future

Now, what does having both spouses working long hours do to home cooking, to raising our kids?  We're not living like middle class anymore and we probably never will again.

>>> COMMENT UNDER ANALYSIS<<<


You definitely can--if you do all your cooking yourself, which takes more time. It's not just the fact content that you have to worry about; beans, rice, etc contain a large amount of carbohydrates and you need to eat a lot in order to get enough protein. On top of that there are certain nutrients that are almost impossible to get such as B12 without supplementation, which would make you permanently reliant on a lab.

It's not a bad short term diet, and I know people who do fine on it for years, but there is serious doubt among the nutritionist community as to whether or not the diet can be sustained for life.

>>> END COMMENT <<<

# News comment title:
GOP Aims to Sink Navy's "Great Green Fleet"

# Oldest comment (from the thread):
Our proud Navy cannot sit still. We must have the will to drill, baby, drill. Soybeans & methane are out with the swill.

# Most liked comment (from the thread):
Too many have  missed the Point. The BIG Picture. If the Worlds Largest War Machine can run on Bio fuel and not Fossil Fuels, we all can. Fossil Fuels are a thing of the past. The USPS was going to do this and they announced it to the world back in 2006 and immediately the Bush administration passed a bill that had a Kill Pill in it and the USPS had to put the project on hold. The USPS was out to lead by example being that they have (outside of the Military) the single largest continuous moving fleet all over the US and Puerto Rico. If the USPS could operate 100% gas free, so could the average American. Nuclear is Not an Option. More so than Fossil Fuel, Nuclear is so yesterday its pathetic. Nuclear's destructive by product will continue to hold us at bay for Millions of years to come. There is one Big Picture being shown to us all by our Military, unlike the bought and paid for Politicians (most of which are Republicans), and unlike the corporate Lords that own the For Profit Auto and Oil industries, Our/we the people's Military is Leading down this Path for a better, cleaner Tomorrow. For good or for bad, A Mean Clean Fighting WAR Machine. No matter how fast you throw spears at the Sun, it will not stop the Sun from bringing you Tomorrow. It still Surprises me to this day, what little people know about our Military, everything we use as a Society, as individuals, from computers to Nuclear Medicine, clean water, Vehicles, Microwaves to heat our food, cell phones, GPS systems, even bridges and so on into infinity was brought to us free of charge (except for Taxes), by our Military.     

>>> COMMENT UNDER ANALYSIS<<<


Don't get me wrong; I think we should invest in bio-fuels and have been pushing a local college to build a scale bio-fuel energy production plant. I just don't know if navy vessels are the best place to use it. Nuclear subs go for their entire commissioned life time without the need for refueling; they do not produce any green house gasses during energy production.

In any case, if we just slashed the size of our military we could reduce the amount of fossil fuels used real fast so perhaps that's the best choice.

>>> END COMMENT <<<

Again I was talking about Thorium and not Uranium and no it is not a theoretical project. Reactors are starting to be switched over to Thorium now. There already were smaller model reactors. This is not an on paper idea.

# News comment title:

# Oldest comment (from the thread):

I'd say making 200,000 or more a year is rich because it means you make more then 98% of Americans; however Republicans have said that making 200,000 a year is middle class further proving that republicans are idiots

>>> COMMENT UNDER ANALYSIS<<<


You are correct. I have not been to Japan but I have studied it in a fair amount of detail.

That sentence seems way too formal to be natural. Nihonjin ja nai.

In any case, the point is that after Japan attempted to stimulate its economy, there was a long period of economic stagnation. Japan has since averaged near zero economic growth (meaning negative growth in terms of output per capita). Prices in Japan are quite high, and while there is a high level of employment, that often does not meet the demands of the high cost of living.

The other issue is that poverty in Japan is not so out in the open making it difficult to get a real handle on the level. Most estimates are probably under estimates, not over estimates.

http://www.economist.com/node/21549003

http://www.google.com/url?sa=t&rct=j&q=&esrc=s&source=web&cd=2&cad=rja&ved=0CD8QFjAB&url=http%3A%2F%2Fwww.japantimes.co.jp%2Ftext%2Ffl20120520rp.html&ei=YJLlUOraOuSA0AHknoDwAQ&usg=AFQjCNGz08JdUL8FpQl-BEV37dgziZjnHA&sig2=_rmK_c6_qVTMyFlDxtf26Q&bvm=bv.1355534169,d.dmQ

http://www.csmonitor.com/World/Asia-Pacific/2012/0814/Japan-s-poverty-gap-has-politicians-calling-for-rise-in-minimum-wage (my prediction, no change or a worsening of the situation if they raise the minimum wage)

I can go on, but I think that's good for now.

>>> END COMMENT <<<

May the power of Christ compel you!!

>>> COMMENT UNDER ANALYSIS<<<


We definitely have a different view on government. I see it as a natural consequence of human interaction, but not a positive one. One could think of government as a rock and a hill. The top of the hill is flat and the rock just sits there, but once the rock gets going, its natural tendency is to roll downhill until it crushes what's below, and the only way to prevent this is to constantly push back against the rock, after all, even just letting the rock be, it will roll down hill.

In this case the rock rolling down hill is the centralization of control and the loss of freedom by the people. However instead of pushing back against the rock to prevent it from crushing what's below, the majority of people now are on the other end of the rock trying to push it down faster!

I highly doubt we'd be able to come to a middle ground on this concept because of vastly differing views, but it's still interesting to discuss opposing view points. After all, I don't expect someone to just randomly say, "you know, you're right, government's rubbish", but maybe the idea of a decentralized control structure will peak an interest.

>>> END COMMENT <<<

Another important connection here is that these inputs all kill the microbial life in the soil. Restoring land means building up carbon in humus, roots, beneficial fungi that supply minerals from subsoil, bacteria, worms, and countless little beasties that (shut up, Monsanto!) are mainly GOOD for plants and soil.

# News comment title:
Here's Another Way the GOP Is Undermining Obamacare

# Oldest comment (from the thread):
as a retiree, my sympathies are with these people worried about changing policies. But I want to question how come insurance premiums vary so much between states? One couple in the story paid around $1,000 a month? With a huge deductible.


I have full coverage and no deductible, and have my eyes checked every year or as needed, and dental coverage. My insurance is going down by $20 a month, but I pay about $360 a month for all of that. I do have a secondary policy, that covers most of my co-pays. If I didn't have that 2nd policy, my co-pay for a regular doctor would be $20, for an ER visit $50.


We need a national health care plan that just seems more apparent every day.

Big corporations are unnatural entities in the free market. Government manipulates the dynamics of the market and changes what can evolve within it. Walmart is always a good example, since it relies so heavily on the government. So let's examine that institution.

Walmart's net profits for the last few years have averaged around $16B. Walmart receives roughly $14B in revenue from food stamps. Continuing with food stamps for a moment, the average Walmart employee would not be able to survive on their current pay, without the existence of food stamps. Now, a big government supporter might say, "see, this is why we need food stamps", but realize that without these programs, Walmart would have no choice but to pay their employees more or else they would simply lose their work force! So, that would be another huge added cost without government.

In addition, it receives one sided tax breaks that small businesses wouldn't receive. Not only that, but they use eminent domain in order to obtain property that they normally would not be able to obtain or would only be able to obtain at a far higher price.

However, the support Walmart receives doesn't end there! One of the reasons that a lot of the products are so inexpensive at Walmart, especially the food, is because of the government subsidization of agriculture, which artificially deflates the price of foods produced by mega corporations and sold by institutions like Walmart.

# News comment title:
Obama Goes off on Mass Shootings

# Oldest comment (from the thread):
I don't understand why such intelligent people are feeding into this theory that more gun control is going to get guns out of the hands of people who shouldn't have them. In my town, there are unregistered guns, bought illegally, hidden all over the place. As long as you know where they are, you can just go to the drop spot, use the gun, and then rehide it and let everyone know where it is. But sure...gun control's gonna stop that.

# Most liked comment (from the thread):
Because Australia.

You are making the point, actually.  In your town, there are guns everywhere.  That's exactly the problem.  If there were fewer of them, there'd be less problem.

Offer buybacks for the guns that are out there.  Nobody's confiscating your guns, but if you'd like to make some cash discarding some of the extras you've got, it's your choice.

Restrict new gun purchases to defensive and sporting weapons only.  You don't need weapons of war (offensive weapons) unless you want to join the "well-regulated militia".  We already don't generally let civilians buy M-60 machine guns, all we're doing is moving that dividing line further down the scale.  Even Justice Scalia said the 2nd Amendment isn't absolute.

Lifetime ownership.  You buy a gun, its serial number and ballistic prints are registered to you for life.  Your only transfer options are the buyback program or passing it down to family who then get the lifetime ownership.  If your gun is used to harm another, you get 50% of whatever punishment the shooter gets.  Theft of your gun is no defense - gee, didn't you have a gun to deter theives?  (Wanna bet folks will be extra careful to lock up their guns?)


Bullet control.  The 2nd Amendment protects the right to bear arms.  It doesn't say a thing about ammo.  Regulate the hell out of ammo purchases.  Background check for every purchase.  Quantity limits.  You name it.

When I hear "guns don't kill people, people kill people" I think I agree, and it seems that the people in the United States like to kill people quite often with guns.  When I hear "it's mental health, it's culture" I think I agree, and it seems we have a crazy killing culture.  If we're such a crazy killing nation, perhaps we should have fewer guns to crazily kill each other with.

>>> COMMENT UNDER ANALYSIS<<<


Okay. Here we go again. Gun laws do not reduce violent crime rates. Unless we can fix the underlying causes of these mass killings, we won't change anything. In addition, while the mass killings are certainly big "news" they account for only a small fraction of violent crimes in this country. It's just easier for the average person, who can only focus on a few things at a time, to relate to large scale events.

>>> END COMMENT <<<

# News comment title:
Math: The Ultimate BS Detector

# Oldest comment (from the thread):
another interesting article. Lately I have seen how mathematics has something to do with music, amusement parks, and all kinds of things that w use everyday.  I never thought about us having these things because somebody knowing about math. I have a new appreciation growing for math.

# Most liked comment (from the thread):
Yeah; I call b.s. here. Intellectual Property laws. Welfare programs. Taxation. They all benefit mega corporations. Naked Capitalism? What we have in this country, and in most other nations, is crony capitalism: essentially government supported capitalism where a few corporations are selected to become domesticated livestock and are fattened up at the expense of all of the other businesses in the market.

>>> COMMENT UNDER ANALYSIS<<<


I have never argued that we can get away from a mixed economy. Government will always try to form and manipulate the market system. I am arguing that we should do our best to allow free market dynamics to resolve our resource management problem.


Singapore is a pretty good example of limited government at play. It is not a perfect example by any means, but there you go. Even European nations that are performing at their best, while not exactly small, have far less influence on their markets because they are far more decentralized, increasing competition and decreasing the spread of corruption.


People use Somalia as the counter example to libertarian policies, but when you actually study Somalia, besides learning that the system in place is in on way voluntary and the current state of affairs are the result of massive government intervention via imperialism and civil war, you'll find that after the fall of the last major government, most of the socioeconomic indicators improved.


I am argue for the least amount of government with the most decentralized topology that we can push to get. Nothing more.

>>> END COMMENT <<<

# Most liked comment (from the thread):

Like most discussions of democractizing programming skill, this one
misses a crucial point:

Knowing how to program will get you nowhere when you use
a program that users are not allowed to study or change.

When does this happen?  If you are running a program that's not
free/libre, whose source code is secret, you're blocked at the start.
If the program is running in some company's server, a "cloud" gets in
the way as you try to change it.

To make computing democratic, the users must control the software
that does their computing!

See http://gnu.org/philosophy/free-software-even-more-important.html
and http://gnu.org/philosophy/who-does-that-server-really-serve.html.

Richard Stallman

MacArthur Fellow

2. I looked up the case. I don't see any reference to the preamble in the summary, but I'll keep looking. Regardless, it is generally agreed that the preamble is in no way legally binding and is not to be used in jurisprudence.

Law is shaped by the way the majority of the justices rule at the time, but that does not change whether or not a law is constitutional. Constitutionality is set by the constitution and nothing else. It is simply an obligation of the Supreme Court to rule in accordance with it.


And in the case of whether or not the constitution grants the government the authority to regulate immigration, even the SCOTUS has come to the conclusion that the power doesn't rest with the constitution but with so called inherent powers of a sovereign nation.


However, answer this: what becomes of the tenth amendment in light of the concept of inherent powers of the federal government? I'm sure your sixth grade civics class went over that, yes?

# News comment title:
How Monsanto's Big Data Push Hurts Small Farms

# Oldest comment (from the thread):
one of the more sensible articles I've read on this site in months... thx.

# Most liked comment (from the thread):
What Monsanto (and the rest) really want are bigger profits, and their biggest product to date has been LIES. GREAT BIG JUICY LIES. Why would you waste my time and yours regurgitating this PR garbage? For the past 30 years they've absolutely pounded us with the claim that "GMOs MEAN LESS PESTICIDE USE." Turns out to be their biggest lie yet. Instead, we're using more pesticides than ever because the weeds and the bugs have developed immunity. Which is why the gentech crowd now wants to use on our food the same super poisons they used during the war in Southeast Asia.
"GMOs MEAN BIGGER HARVESTS." Sure, for the first couple of years, and then the lie becomes truly apparent when GMOs give you SMALLER harvests than the conventional seeds you were using.. at higher costs. This is one of the lies that has led to widespread failure of mom&pop farms: they were told to expect great things and ended up drowning in debt. And while there's plenty of press about suicide rates AMONG FARMERS in India the media hardly ever mentions the suicides occurring in other parts of the world like Australia where church groups have created suicide watch squads to keep an eye on farmers driven into debt'n'desperation by Monsanto and their agtech comrades. 
What about the "FEED THE WORLD" lie? Conventional plant breeders and small farms supply more than 75% of the world's food, and agribusiness provides debt'n'degradation for human health and Mother Nature with tons of poisons that fill our air and water. The TRUTH is that it's NOT getting better.
Last, but not least, is the lie about "SAFETY." Since our tax dollars are no longer used to do the testing and analysis of GMOs and the chemical poisons stream we have no way of knowing if the testing that's SUPPOSEDLY being done by Monsanto&Friends is on the up'n'up.
How did companies whose main products have been poisons and biological weapons of war get control of food policy for much of the known world? First, by telling lies, AND, by paying big dividends to politicians, professors, and reporters.
A leopard cannot change its spots. In this case those spots are named PCB's, DDT, 2-4-D, RoundUp, Aspartame, Saccharin, Bovine Growth Hormone, Agent Orange, and more. Certainly enough toxic spots to to cover the animal, AND, to let us know without any doubt that we're dealing with a wild and dangerous beast. This article just represents our willingness to swallow more lies. (sigh)
For decades I was able to feed family and neighbors for blocks around with a huge variety of fruits and vegetables from relatively small gardens, without a huge amount of work. I did so with the same knowledge my mother and grandfather got from their parents and grandparents. Not one chemical. Not one GMO. Currently we have one-and-a-half times the food needs of every individual on the planet, and most of that food ends up dumped in the ocean. Big Ag has a great racket going and the taxpayers are footing the bill. And the media falls all over itself to lend a hand.

Nothing beneficial and quite a bit that's harmful. The problem is, welfare programs for mega corps are often masked as welfare programs for the masses. Such programs take revenue out of the economy as a whole and transfer it to the companies that focus on foodstamp sales. Walmart is the largest recipient. More States Are Letting Parents Refuse to Vaccinate Their Kids

# Oldest comment (from the thread):
Parents may, currently, have the right to not vaccinate their kids.  We, as a society, have the right to ensure that those kids do not infect others.  Keep them out of school and other public places.

# Most liked comment (from the thread):
Parents may, currently, have the right to not vaccinate their kids.  We, as a society, have the right to ensure that those kids do not infect others.  Keep them out of school and other public places.

>>> COMMENT UNDER ANALYSIS<<<


Herd immunity CAN exist for some vaccines, but for which ones does it currently exist? I can tell you that it is likely that it does not exist for Pertussis. You seem to think that I don't have any understanding of medical science. I do. And yeah, I can read a study just fine. Here are a few:

"Acellular pertussis vaccines protect against disease but fail to prevent infection and transmission in a nonhuman primate model" and "Pertussis infection in fully vaccinated children in day-care centers, Israel" discuss asymptomatic carriers resulting from incomplete vaccination. I'm on a tablet and switching tabs causes the page to reload, so I can't get the exact article names for the others.

Zhang et al. 2014 attempts to get an idea of how many asymptomatic carriers there are. In that study, Chinese school aged children (7 - 15), who are asymptomatic, are tested for Pertussis using both cultures and PCR. PCR came back positive 4.8% of the time. Note that this is not annual positive cases. This is a snapshot. What does that mean for the United States? Well, assuming that we have only 10% of that rate in the US (just to give myself tons of buffer space) that would still mean that at any given time there are about 150,000 asymptomatic cases. I would love to set up a study to test that, but like I said, I gave myself a lot of room for error. The last study that I will cite is something along the lines of "Modeling the Effects of Carriers on Transmission..."

Basically, if the parameters are correct, you would see an increase in the rate of infection rather than a decrease, and with 150,000+ carriers among school aged children... well...

> But, you know, keep on believing that it doesn't. As someone who holds graduate degrees in hard sciences and whose entire family are in the science and public health fields as doctors and researchers

This is called appeal to authority. It is fallacious if either (1) you are not an authority, and holding a degree in a hard science does not make you an authority,  or (2) the other person has made a specific argument, which I have. By the way, what "hard sciences" are your degrees in?

Yeah. I'd be happy to find my 50-year-old certificate from a country I don't live in any more to show at LAX. And when you come to my country, you can show me yours. Certificate for school entry, sure. For international travel? Don't be silly.

>>> COMMENT UNDER ANALYSIS<<<


Do you really want to keep talking after embaressing yourself when you mentioned whole cell pertussis vaccines? Okay.

1. Fine. I shouldn't have said "that's obvious." However, it is a reasonable hypothesis that the risk associated with vaccination is at least additive.

2. Again, you're ignoring the impact of asymptomatic carriers on rates of infection. It requires the correct parameters, but it certainly is possible. And as I said, we are seeing asymptomatic carriers in fully vaccinated populations and in mostly vaccinated populations.

I am currently working on a compartmental model specific to B. pertussis and related species. I am utilizing existing work on two models: an S-I-Ic-R model which takes into account asymptomatic carriers (but does not consider the carriers to be infectious) and an S-I-V-R model which takes into account waning immunity.

The problem with B. pertussis studies is that the carriers seem to be infectious and the vaccine's efficacy wanes rapidly. Therefore both factors need to be taken into account.

But consider the Chinese study (I can link to it if you want). 0.3% of the sample tested positive through culture samples and 4.8% through PCR. Now since the former underestimates by a lot and the latter has a tendency to create false positives, it's still difficult to get a handle on how many infections there are, but assume the 0.3% and scale that to Americans aged 7 - 15. You're still talking 150,000. We can't get a handle on how common this infection is if we do not have an idea of how many carriers there are.

# News comment title:
Satanic Reverses: Religious Exceptions Are A Real Win For Devil Worshippers

>>> COMMENT UNDER ANALYSIS<<<


Ah. Sorry. I edited this post for additional information that you must not have seen:

** Edit: In addition you have yet to show how such a restriction comes from Lemon v. Kurtzman which says that a law can neither advances nor inhibits religion.

If you are arguing that such requirements that a warden cannot force a person to go to church, does restrict (inhibit) religion, then a simple logical test will suggest that its validity does not come from the Lemon test.

Let's make this simpler. We'll convert the Lemon test to a mathematical sentence.

phi(x) = ¬ (x advances religion ∨ inhibits religion) where the truth value of phi(x) is the constitutionality of x.

You admit that x inhibits religion, yes? Then you have:

phi(x)
= ¬ (U ∨ T)
= ¬ T
= F

Thus by the Lemon test, x is unconstitutional.

Is phi(x) incorrect, because you already stated that x inhibits religion.

The Lemon law basically prevented any law from giving support to a religion. Your argument seems to be that without x, religion would advance, but we do not discuss the constitutionality of absence of law. That makes no sense. We can only address whether a law is constitutional or not. And according ot the test that you provided, x is not constitutional.

# News comment title:
Why Would an Economic Analysis Want to Ignore American Slavery?

# Oldest comment (from the thread):
I'm OK with him calling a country that prospered thanks to genocidal expansion and slavery the one, true libertarian government. 

# Most liked comment (from the thread):
That and the fact that no one likes to listen to dudes (and let's face it, they're almost always dudes) born on third base lecture everyone else on the virtues of hitting triples.

>>> COMMENT UNDER ANALYSIS<<<


YNWA40515, no libertarian has? Well, then I guess I must be the first. Consider markets, and the larger anthroposystems (analogous to ecosystems) as a whole, and view them like you would a biological system (really they are biological systems - just inorganic). 

Evolutionary dynamics drives a system away from such accumulation of wealth since it reduces net effective return on energy. Monopolies, while useful in some instances, are short lived with evolutionary dynamics in place, as models which reproduce generally outlast those that do not. Now continuing our biological analogy/extension, we have that governments act essentially as domesticators. They manipulate other entities in the anthrosphere, which creates mutual benefit and reliance between them, at the expense of entities which are not being domesticated.

This brings us to your next assertion: "and that they pretty much always do and have [accumulated wealth]."

Consider any entity which has negatively impacted the anthrosphere. I would argue that the majority of them are domesticated entities or weeds. I would also argue that the probability of selecting such an entity which is not dometicated drops as the length of time it managed to survive increases.

Consider the Robber Barons. They emerged because of the government push for railroad infrastructure. Consider the mafia, and then later the mega breweries. The first was an example of a weed, and the latter an example of a domesticated entity, both related to prohibition.

So, you can no longer say that no libertarian has demonstrated why it must be true under libertarianism.

>>> END COMMENT <<<

# News comment title:
Clinton Beats Sanders, 50-50

# Oldest comment (from the thread):
To me one of the biggest take-aways from last night was Clinton's organizational prowess - ie., her caucus operation.

In 2008 it was her failure to perform well in caucus states -- more than any single factor I'd argue -- that caused her loss to Obama. I've read in numerous places  she roughly fought the Obama campaign to a draw in the raw primary vote. Maybe even eked out a slight advantage.

But Axelrod's caucus operation was devastatingly effective. And helped the Obama campaign to a modest but early delegate lead. Which it never relinquished. And this lead in turn early on signaled to voters that Obama was for real. Which in turn before long created irreversibly grim delegate math for the Clinton campaign.

Anyway, the Clinton campaign's successful emulation of Obama 2008 tactics (or, if you like, its success in learning from '08's mistakes) is about the worst news Sanders could possibly have received last night.

# Most liked comment (from the thread):
If Clinton 2016 considers Iowa a "win," there's a bridge in Brooklyn I'd like to sell them.

>>> COMMENT UNDER ANALYSIS<<<


Then why have them?

We've Barely Begun to Tap the Sun’s Mighty Power

# Oldest comment (from the thread):
Best thing about rooftop PV (solar) is that it does not make any new disturbance on the environment, and since the grid is already at the building, it helps to take the strain off it. 
Solar is uniquely suited to small installations, which makes it a very good bet.

# Most liked comment (from the thread):
Best thing about rooftop PV (solar) is that it does not make any new disturbance on the environment, and since the grid is already at the building, it helps to take the strain off it. 
Solar is uniquely suited to small installations, which makes it a very good bet.

>>> COMMENT UNDER ANALYSIS<<<


Production, longevity, other impacts on the environment aside from energy greenhouse gasses (byproducts of mining for the panels), location (remember that panels in regions, closer to the poles, are going to produce less power than those closer to the equator), all have an impact on whether or not solar makes sense. There are locations where solar does make sense, but not everywhere, and it doesn't mean that solar, and other related technologies, will be able to fully replace other energy sources, especially within a reasonable period of time.

# News comment title:
Is This Early Stage Vaccine Our Best Hope Against Zika?

# Oldest comment (from the thread):
It'll be interesting to see if Congress actually gets off its ass and appropriates the money they need.

# Most liked comment (from the thread):
"... we could not get any company to partner with us for advanced development because there was not the perception by any company that this was a vaccine that would be widely used. So we never brought it into phase IIb."

This is a near perfect example of the sort of market failure that for-profit health care engenders.

Public health is a public good: which is why governments, not private, for profit corporations should be funding these efforts.

>>> COMMENT UNDER ANALYSIS<<<


Okay. You have the technosphere, which is basically all resources created by, used by, and shared by people, including labor, business, etc (analogous to the biosphere). A division of the technosphere is an anthroposystem (analogous to an ecosystem). Within an anthroposystem, there are market entities and there are non-market entities. Governments are non-market entities, but they are not the only non-market entities. 

Now, while I will agree with the assertion that market entities alone are unable to handle externalities and public goods, there are non-market entities which can, such as cooperatives, charities, unions, guilds, etc. In other words, just because the market alone would fail does not mean that the government need step in to handle these problems.

>>> END COMMENT <<<
